text:
Q: Does it matter which vendor's JDK you build with? A:

Update: OpenJDK

Lots of chance since this Question posted.

Oracle acquired Sun Microsystems, and is the current owner of the Java trademark and related technologies. Oracle then open-sourced its implementation of Java as the OpenJDK project. This included the HotSpot performance technology from Sun. Oracle also incorporated aspects of its JRockit technology previously acquired.

IBM joined the OpenJDK project, open-sourcing and contributing much code. Apple joined the OpenJDK project too, contributing its Mac-specific codebase and other technologies.

IBM also open-sourced its IBM J9 product as OpenJ9, to be used with OpenJDK as an alternate to HotSpot/JRockit. Other are excellent technologies, with OpenJ9 being somewhat quicker to launch, and HotSpot/JRockit being somewhat more efficient over long runs.

Most of the Java ecosystem has centered on using the OpenJDK codebase for implementing Java. Several companies provide JDK/JRE products based largely, if not entirely, on the OpenJDK codebase. These vendors include:

  • Azul Systems
  • Red Hat
  • IBM
  • BellSoft
  • Oracle
  • SAP
  • Adoptium, The Eclipse Foundation
  • Amazon
  • Microsoft

… and more.

You can compile your Java app using a JDK from any of these vendors. They all emit the Java bytecode compliant with the Java specifications, all thoroughly tested. A Java app compiled by any of the JDK from any of these vendors can be executed on a Java Virtual Machine of a JDK or JRE from any other vendor; you can mix-and-match.

For more details, see the whitepaper Java Is Still Free, written by pillars of the Java community.

The above discussion applies to general purpose Java apps. For special purposes, you may be interested in GraalVM technology. These purposes include native-compilation, and polyglot programming integration with various languages.

Q: Configure module-level logger as child of main program logger A:

You could get the logger and reset its name:

import httpx
import logging


if __name__ == "__main__":
    logging.basicConfig(
        format="%(levelname)s [%(name)s] %(message)s",
        level=logging.INFO,
    )
    logging.getLogger("httpx").name = "blort"
    httpx.get("https://www.example.com")

Result:

INFO [blort] HTTP Request: GET https://example.org "HTTP/1.1 200 OK"

Disclaimer, the docs say that the name attribute should be treated as read-only. So, proceed with caution.

Q: Invalid Scopes: email, openid, public_profile A:

2025

Managed to resolved mine by customizing Authenticate and request data from users with Facebook Login and added 'email' and 'public_profile'.

Also indicated both on the permission: (Flutter)

final LoginResult loginResult = await FacebookAuth.instance.login(
    permissions: ['public_profile', 'email']
);

Q: Shifting string values to a previous column in a dataframe A:

Welcome to Stack Overflow! Please take the tour. This is a Q&A site, so what do you want to ask? You've described a problem, but what's stopping you from solving it? Check out ask for tips.

And what dataframe library are you using? Pandas? Please add the tag for it.

Also, please don't post pictures of text. Instead, copy the text itself and edit it into your post; you can use print(df) and put it in code formatting or print(df.to_markdown()) which gives you table formatting. See also: How to make good reproducible pandas examples

Q: Are there any standard functions to iterate across predicates by applying to single value? A:

While the Alexandria utility library isn't part of the Common Lisp standard, it is a pretty, ah, common and industrial strength extension.

It has functions disjoin and conjoin, which take one or more predicate functions, and returns a function that calls them in turn on its arguments - disjoin with or like rules, conjoin with and.

A trivial demonstration:

(defun interesting (pred)
  (loop :for n :from -100 :upto 100
    :when (funcall pred n)
      :collect n))

(let ((p (alexandria:conjoin #'integerp #'plusp #'oddp)))
  (print (interesting p)))

Q: Disable activeX warning on excel open A:

This works for me:

  1. In Excel, right-click the menu bar ("Ribbon")

  2. Choose "Customize the Ribbon".

  3. In "Main tabs" on the right, check on "Developer", and click OK.

  4. Go the the Developer ribbon tab

  5. Click "Macro Security"

  6. Choose "Disable VBA macros without notification", or "Enable VBA macros" (don't enable VBA unless you know what VBA is and the risks. Not needed for normal Excel usage). Click OK.
